In an era of unprecedented levels of human displacement, migration is often reduced to abstract statistics and painted as an immediate, unprecedented issue born of moral binaries and extrahuman forces. The reality, however, is far more complex and difficult to navigate, and involves utilizing mixtures of different approaches to come to a holistic understanding of the situation at hand. Samuel Beckett’s Waiting for Godot and Ai Wei Wei’s Human Flow are two complementary avenues that do so, giving us examples of uncertainty, exclusion, and revealing how not only how our modern system of borders and citizenship often produce individuals forever suspended in limbo, but also the societal psychology that led to their development. By exploring the subject through these two varying perspectives: contrasting Beckett’s abstractions and symbolism with Ai’s realism and groundedness, we’re able to not only understand the psychological causes behind displacement, but also understand the structural conditions that shape migration in the modern world.

In Samuel Beckett’s 1953 play, Waiting for Godot, we follow two men, Vladimir and Estragon, who spend their days waiting beside a barren road for a figure named Godot, whose arrival is repeatedly promised but never fulfilled. Though they consider leaving at various points throughout the play, they remain immobilized by the expectation of Godot’s eventual coming, thus centering the play around a cyclical pattern of anticipation, frustration, and stasis. Writing less than a decade removed from the Second World War, and during the height of the postwar migration crisis plaguing Central and Eastern Europe, Beckett was no doubt heavily influenced by the plight of Czechs, Poles, Germans, and all the various ethnicities whose lives had been interrupted by the brutality of the war years. As such, the repeated cycle of anticipation and hopelessness in Waiting for Godot can thus be seen as both a commentary on the nationalistic fervor that had led to the outbreak of war, and a critique of the ideological divide that blinded Beckett’s contemporaries to prolonging the crisis. At the start of the play, for example, as Estragon struggles with his boot, he complains to Vladimir, “Nothing to be done” (Beckett, 7). Highlighting the pair’s exhaustion with their circumstances, we can draw direct parallels between them and the widespread sense of fatigue which permeated much of Europe in the years following the Second World War. As individuals began to deal with its aftermath and face not only the economic and human costs of it, but also the social and psychological consequences it was having on ethnic identity and ideological disorientation, a sense of hopelessness began to ring out. In response, governments often resorted to radical yet backward-looking solutions, such as the forced resettlement of Poles from Soviet - annexed territories into German lands, and other mass population transfers that attempted to resolve modern problems using the logic of the old order. Rather than breaking the cycle of displacement, these measures merely reproduced it. Echoing this, when the pair begin morbidly debating the subject of whether or not to end their own lives, Estragon and Vladimir state, “Don't let's do anything. It's safer” “Let's wait and see what he [Godot] says” (Beckett, 12). After waiting for days for the arrival of Godot, and seeing no visible change progress, the pair decide upon suicide as the only way to escape the hopelessness of their reality. Even when faced with the finality of their decision, they never act, mirroring the paralysis of a continent unable to act decisively in the depths of crisis. Although new ideologies had spread across Europe, they often replicated the same structures that had only led to past catastrophes. When Europe became divided into East and West, millions sought to flee the Soviet Union and its satellite states, and power dynamics remained fundamentally unchanged, only rebranded under new flags and governments. Finally, perhaps mirroring the cynicism of Beckett’s contemporaries, the play ends as the two debate the idea of their parting ways, stating “It's not worthwhile now” “Well, shall we go?” “Yes, let's go”, only for stage direction to undercut their words: “They do not move” (Beckett, 60). Despite recognizing the futility of waiting, they remain frozen, extolling change while embodying stagnation. In this final scene, Beckett mirrors a Europe seemingly trapped in an endless cycle of war, displacement, and the reassertion of familiar norms. It is here that Waiting for Godot’s relevance to the history of human migration becomes clearest. Even as societies acknowledge the magnitude of displacement, as was the case in a Europe reshaped by the movement of millions, they struggle to articulate frameworks that can bring about any meaningful change. What results is repetition: a cycle that continues into the modern day, as refugees from Ukraine and the Middle East face the same challenges that those from Poland or the Baltics faced seventy years ago.

While Waiting for Godot’s abstract approach to representing migration allows audiences to grasp its psychological causes and the systemic causes that perpetuate it, to understand the immediate causes driving refugees in the modern day, a more concrete lens is needed. Ai Wei Wei’s 2017 documentary Human Flow, centered around the Middle Eastern refugee crisis and its global impacts offers this perspective. Rather than relying on distant statistics or generalized news coverage, Ai focuses on intimate, personal encounters with both those fleeing their homelands, and those inhabiting the countries to which they migrate to. Early in the film, Ai holds an interview with a father cradling his newborn while on a boat departing Greece, capturing the man’s hopes of reaching a country that will assist him so he can one day repay that kindness (Ai, 15:38 - 16:03). Moments like these help the viewer bridge the gap between individual experiences and the overall situation, transforming a global narrative into interpersonal stories. While only a small fraction of individuals in the West will ever flee their homes and seek refuge in a foreign country, the desire to pursue a better future for your children is one that is universal to the human experience, and by centering the narrative on that perspective, the audience is led to move beyond the image of refugees as being faceless masses, and instead recognize them as individuals with familiar outlooks, aspirations, values, and fears. Ai then extends this humanizing approach by turning the camera toward those tasked with enforcing borders. In a later sequence, Hungarian border guards speak candidly about their longing to take leave and return home to their families while continuing to patrol the Serbian border (29:36 - 32:02). By juxtaposing these perspectives, the film resists the binary approach traditional narratives of the situation take, revealing the crisis as one not sustained by mere abstract forces, but by ordinary people navigating their duties and desires. By doing so, Human Flow renders the refugee crisis not only as a geopolitical emergency, but as a human one, shaped by human perspectives and experiences on all sides.

Only after seeing migration and displacement from both perspectives can we begin to truly understand the root causes behind our modern day crisis. Both the psychological and the physical act as counterweights to one another in helping the informed reader resist traditional boolean narratives of a situation so crucial to understanding the contemporary global landscape. Through Waiting for Godot, Beckett illustrates the former through portraying two men waiting for the ever-elusive Godot to arrive and resolve their problems, echoing society’s tendency to defer responsibility to an imagined future rather than confront crises through action in the present. In contrast, Ai Wei Wei’s Human Flow visualizes the latter by grounding the refugee crisis in personal narratives drawn from individuals on both sides of displacement, transcending the overall situation to highlight its human character. Taken together, both works guide the audience towards the understanding that few modern problems, least of all migration, can be reduced to simple moral binaries.

When I was growing up, I always felt like the odd one out at school. Having moved to the United States at the age of five, I spent the first few years of my K - 12 career desperately struggling to catch up with my peers, both in my linguistic abilities and in a cultural context. Because of this, I constantly felt ostracized by my peers. No matter what I did, no matter how hard I tried, I could never fit in with them, resulting in my feeling chronically lonely for those first few years of my academic life.

This all changed sometime during the 3rd grade. This was when I met the person who would become my best friend for the next few years, Grady. On the surface, Grady was no different from those who had shunned me for years. Yet, it was him who, for the first time since I had moved to California, showed me kindness, and allowed me to feel like I belonged. And for that, I am forever grateful, because those actions set me down the path that would lead me to where I am today.

Kindness is seen by many in our modern world as a sign of weakness. “Empathy is sin”, so people say, yet that couldn’t be further from the truth. All the great leaders of our past have shown kindness and compassion in their own way, and all the great villains of history have been those who lacked these traits. To be kind is to show those you lead that you are someone worthy of being followed, someone who truly cares about the causes that they represent, and not just someone who is simply seeking personal gain.
This is why I make showing kindness a matter of the highest priority in my life.

Ever since I’ve been at NYU, I’ve made it a priority to get up early everyday to go to the gym before my classes in the morning. I got into this habit because I realized that after exercising in the mornings, I would always have more energy to deal with the rest of my day.

Shortly after starting this routine, I noticed that my energy levels throughout the day increased considerably. I was more productive, less stressed, and generally functioned better as an individual. Because of my experience with my own schedule, I’m extremely inclined to agree with Dr. Brown’s assertion that play, whether it be exercise or any other activity that allows us to simply destress, plays a vital role in ensuring our wellness as people.

I think that as leaders, we should always be extremely mentally agile. And a key part of mental agility comes from learning to relax your brain, and just allowing yourself to decompress. By incorporating Dr. Brown’s ideas play into my everyday life, I am able to become a better leader simply by ensuring I provide myself with the mental headspace to be able to relax and ensure my own wellbeing.

This, in turn, allows me to become a better leader because I know that my decisions are clearly communicated and coherently planned, something that comes about largely as a result of my commitment to the idea of “play”.

One of my earliest childhood memories is of my grandmother, holding my hand, and taking me to my preschool in Beijing. Due to the realities of Chinese work culture, my parents had a very hectic work schedule, and as a result, for the first few years of my life my grandparents were my primary source of care, supplanting the roles of my father and mother as they worked long hours to provide for our family. This led me to develop a very special bond, especially with my grandmother, a bond I struggled to let go of for years after my family had moved to the United States, leaving them behind in China.

Such is the reality of life. Slowly, I got used to the impermanent nature of things, and adjusted to the fact that everything around me was constantly changing. This all changed, just last month, a few short days after New Years, when I was woken up in the middle of the night by my mother, shaking me awake and telling me to get dressed; as it turns out, my grandmother had passed away the previous night, and my father was scrambling to get on the next flight to Beijing.

We drove through the dead of night, and as I watched the lights flash by on the interstate, I couldn’t help but think back on the ten years that had passed since I had left my grandmother’s side. So much had changed, yet, despite the distance that separated us, she had always remained a constant presence in my life. Just the knowledge that she was a phone call away had allowed me to persevere through so much; it made the realization that she was gone just that much harder.

Until that point, I had believed that I had built up an immunity to change. After all, once you’ve learned how to adjust to a completely new country, it seems as if the world is your oyster. My grandma’s passing put an end to such delusions. The next few weeks were extremely tough for me. Despite the fact that I might have told myself I was fine, the reality was, I fell apart. It was as if the dam holding back the reality of life from my mind had burst, and I was struggling more than ever to deal with it. Every form of change, whether that be adjusting to college or leaving my friends and family behind all seemed insurmountable to me.

Now, a month later, I am finally beginning to get back on my feet. Yet, I know now that things have changed. I am not immune to change, I know that now; the hardest part is, deciding how to proceed from here.

Jalaludin Rumi’s Guest House is a short poem outlining a method for which people should try and process the various emotions they deal with throughout their lives. He utilizes a guest house as a metaphor for the brain, and speaks of welcoming in new emotions into the brain as one would welcome guests into a guest house, embracing them instead of rejecting them, as they can aid in personal growth. As someone currently undergoing tremendous change in my personal life, I find this idea both unfamiliar, yet appealing.

Understanding how to process one’s emotions is a natural fact of life, and I believe that the first step to doing this is to undergo a process similar to what Rumi suggests: welcoming all emotions into your life, no matter how you may feel about them, as they can only help you grow. While optimistic emotions like happiness, excitement, or pride may be easy for me to process, I’ve often found it difficult to process anger, sadness, jealousy, or all the other negative emotions in my life, and I believe that this is something I have to work on personally if I am going to be able to grow as a person.

I think emotional maturity is one of the fundamental cornerstones of leadership. How can someone who does not possess full mastery over their own mind ever hope to become a leader of others? Having a complete grasp over one’s emotions should be a requirement to all those who seek to be seen as someone who leads, as the ability to make holistic, mature decisions is not something that someone without the right mental headspace can do; the good captain will choose to go down with his vessel not because it is expected of him, but because he has accepted the emotional responsibility of his ship the first day he took command of it.

I’ve always had a difficult relationship with anger. I’ve been a people pleaser for as long as I can remember, and because of that, I often struggle to place myself and my emotions first, including anger. Anger is an emotion I have spent most of my life suppressing, because I’m afraid that if I express it, people will think poorly of me, something I have always been terrified of.

Because of this, I’ve always thought of anger as being an exclusively negative emotion. To me, it’s something that can only bring harm to both myself, and those around me, which is why Lama Owen’s views on the emotion are so fascinating to me. It made me realize that anger might not only be a harbinger of harm, but also something that can be used to improve ourselves. Much like a scale, our emotions need to be balanced in order for us to function, and I think that fits of anger could simply just be our body expressing an imbalance within ourselves.

Lama Owens also touches upon the ability of individual healing to benefit everyone around us, a viewpoint that I’ve long held. I have always been a believer in the idea that you cannot do harm to yourself by doing good for those around you, and vice versa. Keeping in line with this idea, I’ve been volunteering with a Taiwanese Volunteering Agency named Tzu Chi since my Sophomore year of high school. Through them, I’ve been able to do real good for the community around me, whether that be in my hometown in California or here in New York City. Events like handing out Christmas presents to families down by the Mexican border, or hosting a food pantry for the elderly in Chinatown have allowed me to live my life by the principles that both Lama Owens and myself espouse.

I’ve always been very hard on myself. Maybe it stems from my childhood, but I’ve always held myself to a very high standard of excellence, and because of this, when I fail, I tend to have a hard time forgiving myself.

All my life I’ve been told that “failure is a natural part of life”. Yet, to me, it’s never felt this way. I’m very easily discouraged; a bad test score, a rude remark on the street, or the wrong reaction from a friend are all enough to send me spiraling, and I struggle to get back on my feet afterwards. It’s one of the parts of myself that I detest the most; being physically unable to fail in my mind, I constantly sought perfection, and because of this, I tended to fail even harder at the things I’m not good at.

Yet, since I’ve started college, I’ve realized that this way of living isn’t sustainable. We all fail, but what really differentiates the good from the bad is how you handle that failure. Adaptability is also another key part of life, and it’s a part of myself I’ve only recently begun to learn how to get used to.

I think that being able to fail, and thus being able to show vulnerability, is probably one of the most important skills a leader can have. Oftentimes, people will want to follow those within whom they can see themselves within, because it allows them to form a stronger attachment with them. Failure, and by extension, vulnerability, is the greatest way a leader can humanize themselves with the people that they lead. It allows for those under them to see themselves within their leaders, and only strengthen the bond within a team.

I’m a big believer in the idea that “if you love what you do, you never have to work a day in your life”. I think that passion is a crucial component behind being motivated, and that’s why I found Webb’s How to have a Good Day to be so relatable. Looking back, for much of my life, while I considered myself to be hard working, I wasn’t always motivated. Whether that be in school, or in the workplace, if I was given a task, I would do it, but I wouldn’t always devote one hundred percent of my effort to it.

That’s why Omad Safi’s The Disease of Being Busy felt like an intrusion into my soul. All my life I have correlated value with business; whether that be with schoolwork, with internships, with jobs, etc. Maybe it comes from the highly competitive environment I grew up, or the culture that I was born into, but to me, I’ve always equated the idea of idleness with laziness or worthlessness. It’s what made me spend hours upon hours of my childhood reading and studying, it’s what made high school me neglect my relationships to focus on schoolwork and extracurriculars, and it's the same thing that’s driven college me to spend most of my days in Bobst to typing away at my computer.

Yet, in the past, I was always trying to stay busy for the wrong reasons. I wanted to do good at school so I could get into a good college, and go on to have a successful career that made my parents proud. And while most of those goals are still important to me, in the last few months since I’ve been at college I’ve realized that all these goals are much easier to achieve if I am motivated to achieve them. Now, instead of staying busy just for the point of staying busy, I have actual goals I want to work towards, and I enjoy the process of working towards them.

To me, good friends are amongst the most important things in life. They help give you motivation, provide you support during hard times, and are generally necessary given the social nature of human beings.

Although I am very picky with my friends, I have found that having a large social group of people compatible with myself is what’s best for me. It often takes me years to open up to my friends. For example, my friend group in my hometown consists of people I have known for many years now, and they play a crucial role in my life, providing support and companionship anytime I need it.

I think it is because of my pickiness when choosing friends that I find it difficult to be “authentic” with those around me. I am constantly masking my emotions, trying to hide my true thoughts for fear of judgement by my peers. It’s why it took me years to first open up to my friends who I now consider to be as close as family.

This is something I’ve considered to be a hindrance to myself, however. My difficulty to be “authentic” with those around me has instilled me this belief of needing to close myself off, making it difficult for me to form new connections with those around me.

My friends have always been crucial to me. Much like the crutches I used to support myself when I broke my leg, my friends have acted as an emotional crutch for me over the years. When I fall on hard times, I know I can always count on them to support me, and I think that’s why Kate Johnson’s interview resonated so well with me.

In the podcast, Johnson speaks of friendships; real, authentic friends as being a tool that people can use to resist the repressive systems present throughout all of our lives. Much like how I have used my friendships as a tool to resist the negative forces that have impacted me, on a societal level, people can use their friendships as a way to form bonds that are more durable than the oppressive forces that govern their own lives.

I think that meaningful friendships, like the ones that Johnson describes, can be important ways for empowering leaders as, like Johnson describes in the podcast, friendships are an important leg on the journey to becoming more selfless, more generous, and more patient, all important qualities in a leader.

This is something I have noticed firsthand. Through my friendships, I have learned to become a better person. Whether that be going with my friends to go volunteering, or to just act as a source of support for them when they fall on hard times, by finding people I have a connection with, I’ve been able to grow incredibly much as a person.

While many people might think of happiness as something you attain when you achieve all of your goals in life, I think true happiness comes from learning to be content with what you already have. So much of our world is driven by materialistic consumption, and it’s often difficult to just take a step back and really think about what we already have.

It’s also a concept I struggle a lot with. Being content is not something that comes easily to me, or anyone in our modern society, as we’ve been trained to have this instinctive desire to constantly want more from a young age.

Even though I might struggle with this concept, I think that my life does have many of the markings described by Dr. Haidt in The Happiness Hypothesis. For example, my commute everyday to class, and the people I see throughout my day are all conditional factors that have a tremendous impact on my overall happiness level.

Additionally, the friends that I hang out with, the volunteering I do on the weekends, and the hobbies I have are all voluntary activities that play important roles in determining my overall happiness level. I’ve found that I gain tremendous gratification from making progress in the things in my life that I find worth pursuing, whether that be school, or internships, or my extracurriculars.
Overall, I think that my happiness level corresponds well with Dr Haidt’s assessment for determining a person’s overall happiness level.

“The Last Emperor”, a 1987 biopic by Bernardo Bertolucci, is a film covering the life and misfortunes of Puyi, the last emperor of China. It was a movie that I discovered, by chance, as a poster on the wall of a cinema I visited on a field trip in middle school. A striking, unique image, it featured a young boy adorned with a comically large Manchu headgear, standing in front of a seemingly endless crowd of faceless officials all while the enormous gates of the Forbidden City towered over them.

To my adolescent self, the poster had an odd form of hilarity to it. Who was this strange boy? Why were those strange men surrounding him? What led him to wear such a large hat? These were all questions I had, but quickly dropped to fall back in with the rapidity of my plans. Yet, the peculiarity of the poster led the film to stick with me.

Years later, as I was searching for a way to occupy a Saturday night, that poster of The Last Emperor appeared back in my mind. Appearing like an itch that I simply had to scratch, the image I had seen so long ago, combined with a newfound love of history, led me to commit my evening to enjoying the nearly three hour long film. Within just minutes of the opening shot, I had already fallen in love.

What was so special about The Last Emperor to me? When I reflect back on the subject now, I think my fascination with the movie went far deeper than just a poster. It developed from an innate desire within me to see myself, and my culture, portrayed on the big screen. To strip away the sense of mystery that China had always occupied in both my mind and the popular imagination of the western world.

Growing up, the idea of “Oriental Mysticism” always perplexed me. Having been born in China, the idea that Asians were somehow “mysterious” or “enlightened” seemed almost comical to my childhood self. What was so mysterious about me and the land I came from?

These questions gradually faded away as I got older. There simply wasn’t enough time left in the day to debate the grand differences between Eastern and Western civilization when you had AP classes to manage, extracurriculars to maintain, and friends to hang out with.

Yet, overtime, I also found myself falling into this very trap. There existed two Chinas in my head. The China I had known as a child living in Beijing: the modern, yet tradition filled country that was, for lack of a better word, normal. And the image of China I had developed through the media: the fantastical, despotic China, filled with stories of intrigue, heroism, and adventure. Two contrasting images of the same nation, coexisting simultaneously.

I believe this was the reason that The Last Emperor left such a deep impression on me. It was a movie that was able to combine both of these views I had of my homeland in a way that both confirmed them, yet negated them at the same time.

The movie starts out in a gritty, realistic fashion. In 1950, at a train station on the Chinese Soviet border, 44 year old Puyi is returned to China from the Siberian frontier on board a prisoner of war train. Upon entering the station, he immediately darts for the bathroom and attempts to commit suicide by slitting his wrists, but is heroically saved by guards and fellow prisoners. The grim, dark colors of the scene combined with the brutality of its contents demonstrate the harsh reality that Puyi finds himself in, and the brutalist nature of the set design show off the sense of hopelessness very much present throughout the China of that era.

This is immediately contrasted by the following scene. Taking place in 1908, we follow a fantastical parade of soldiers and courtiers through the streets of Beijing to carry away a young Puyi, then just three years old, from his mother to be taken to the Imperial palace, where he is to be made Emperor following the death of his uncle, the Guanxu Emperor. While most of the scene is shot in the night, the difference in tone is evident through the soundtrack and tone, which both set an atmosphere of tense excitement.

These two scenes set the tone for the rest of the film. The Last Emperor is a film of contrasts, of a combination of fantastical and brutalist elements, simultaneously working together to create an image of China that goes far beyond the typical stereotyping of Western and Eastern filmmakers. Scenes like Puyi’s first and second coronations, mixed with the shelling of the Forbidden City by warlord forces work together to paint an image of a nation that is both still rooted in tradition, but also plagued by the problems of modernity. It’s a country where one’s fantastical imagination can still run wild, yet also remain grounded in reality.

It’s for these reasons that when I finally got to the end of the first of many rewatches of the Last Emperor that Saturday night so long ago, I was so enamored. It was a movie that encapsulated the subconscious ideals I had of a country I felt such a deep connection to, yet had rarely seen since I had left it over a decade ago. These ideals drew me to the film, and by allowing me to express these ideas through film, they also helped to change my very view of the world around me.

Walker Percy’s essay The Loss of the Creature is an essay of questions. Deep, existential questions like: why do we find meaning in the things that we do? How do we perceive the world around us through the lens of society? What can we do to attain a more unbiased, holistic perspective of the experiences we experience? These are all problems that have plagued mankind since the days of Plato and Aristotle, yet, why is it that despite all the strides we have made since those days, we are still no closer to answering them?

In his essay, Percy does not try to answer these questions, but merely shares with us his viewpoint of them. By giving various rhetorical examples, such as a man from Boston who journeys to the Grand Canyon for a vacation, an American couple road tripping through Mexico, or a high school student in a biology lab, why is it that our expectations never truly match up with reality? How come, when we witness something for the first time, we often feel disappointed, no matter how grand the spectacle is? Through the perspectives of these characters that Percy creates, we are able to experience firsthand some of the fundamental reasons behind why we ask these questions.

The loss of real experiences, as Percy describes it, has been a slow, but steady process. Through our increasing reliance on outside experts, “those who know” (Percy, 3), we have gradually eroded our own ability to experience new things for ourselves. Our traveler, seeing the Grand Canyon for the first time, is “aware that something is wrong. He may simply be bored; or
he may be conscious of the difficulty: that the great thing yawning at his feet somehow

eludes him” (Percy, 1). Our couple, after spending hours lost in the Mexican hinterland, stumble upon an Indian village participating in “a corn dance in supplication of the rain god”; “this is ‘it’”, they tell themselves, yet their reaction is merely a mask,  “a rather desperate impersonation”, driven “by their anxiety that it may not prove to be so perfect”, that at any moment a “fellow Iowan might emerge from a ‘dobe hut; the chief might show them his Sears catalog” (Percy, 3). The student, given a Dogfish to dissect, does not truly appreciate the miracle of life that is in front of him. All he sees is “1 specimen of Squalus acanthias”, making the Dogfish become “a rather shabby expression of an ideal reality”, leading to a “radical devaluation of the individual dogfish” (Percy, 5). He sees the creature in front of him not as a sentient individual, but merely as a tool through which he is taught to become “one who knows”.

But what drives us to think this way? Tempting as it may to frame the answer to this problem from a 21st century perspective, Percy, the man behind these observations, wrote them decades before the internet was invented, living in a world where only a few dozen transcontinental phone calls could be made at a time and where many people still corresponded solely through pen and paper. To him, the answer to this lies in the appropriation “by the symbolic complex which has already been formed in the sightseer’s mind” (Percy, 1). It stems from our brain’s inability to think, to experience the world for ourselves, degrading man into waiving “his sovereign rights as a person” and accepting “his role of consumer” as being “the highest estate to which the layman can aspire” (Percy, 6). We are forced into accepting the stifled role of our minds in processing the human condition, and through this we become overly reliant on merely gazing, capturing, but never understanding. These are all issues familiar to us in our hyperconnected world, yet if these same issues were being addressed by Percy so long ago, where does the origin behind them lie? With the invention of the telephone? Mass media? The advent of industrialization?

In the Valley of the Kings in Egypt, there lies a tomb dedicated to the Egyptian Pharaohs Ramses V & VI, built over three thousand years ago and opened long ago during antiquity. Despite its age, what captures the attention of many people today is not the tomb itself, of which there are many in the region, but rather what is carved into its walls.

Scattered all throughout the tomb are carvings etched into the stone not by the original builders of the tomb, but rather by ancient tourists from around the Mediterranean, most notably Rome and Greece, reminiscing on their travels. When translated, their subjects range from humorous or critical statements, like “I cannot read the hieroglyphs”, to poetic quotes like “I was here” or “I admired” (The Archaeologist, 2022). Much as the modern tourist loses sight of the exoticism of the Grand Canyon, becoming and desperately seeking to rise above complacency through photography or forced exclamations, so too were the architects of civilization yearning fervently for a way of forever preserving their own mediocre experiences by attempting to weave a part of their journeys into the wider tapestry of the tomb.

It goes to show then, that preconceived societal notions of how we should view the world around us have existed for far longer than just recent memory. Despite the fact that Romans preceded the striking of the first steel beams or the running of the first steam engines by two thousand years, they too were slaves to the same societal pressures we commonly associate with industrial and post industrial society. We as humans must have some innate desire to want to generate symbolic complexes, trying to either find value in the absence of it, or underappreciating the magnificent just as it is presented to us. So if such desires to reinforce predicated notions of value are so important to us, are they truly a problem in themselves? Societies and civilizations are built off artificial notions of values, so it must be asked, is Percy justified in questioning the very things that give us our modern way of life? The man from Boston, upon arriving at the Grand Canyon, might be disappointed by what he sees because of preconceived notions of what it should look like, formed through years of exposure to it in the popular imagination. Yet without the avenues through which he has been exposed to these ideas, his modern way of life could not exist. The tourism agency with which he came to the Grand Canyon only exists because society necessitates its existence, as the masses demand access to exotic experiences, however disappointing they might turn out. The money with which he purchases his vacation is earned by working in a job, created by society to give its members redeemable rewards for labor. Our modern way of life is fueled by society, by its expectations and social structures; would we truly be freer if we rid ourselves of these institutions in order to recover our individuality?

I believe that the origins of Percy’s “dissatisfaction” with societal norms, and his emphasis on the individual over the collective, can be traced back to his life experiences. While born into a relatively prominent Southern family, (with his relatives having held roles in the Confederate government and the US Senate), Percy’s life would be quickly turned upside down when, at the age of just thirteen, his father took his own life in the aftermath of the Wall Street Crash of 1929. This catastrophic event threw his family into turmoil, leading his mother to join his father just two years later, while Percy was sent to live with a distant cousin in Mississippi.

A tragedy as large as the loss of his parents undoubtedly demonstrated to the young Percy how fragile our lives truly are. Despite all the wealth and power his family held, none of it was enough to prevent the death of his parents, and the ensuing fallout that followed. Our overreliance on society for support, approval, or validation can have disastrous consequences, and when we can no longer rely on those around us, only the individual remains.

As such, it comes as no surprise that isolation plays a big role in Percy’s works. Throughout The Loss of the Creature, Percy utilizes examples where the individual is completely isolated from civilization as a way of demonstrating the power of sovereignty over oneself. In Percy’s mind, for example, the truest way of gaining true experience is through staunch individualism, and we see this all through the essay, like when he states that “The most extreme case of access by privilege … is the Huxleyan novel of the adventures of the surviving remnant after the great wars of the twentieth century. An expedition from Australia lands in Southern California and heads east. They stumble across the Bright Angel Lodge, now fallen into ruins. The trails are grown over, the guard rails fallen away, the dime telescope at Battleship Point rusted. But there is the canyon, exposed at last. Exposed by what? By the decay of those facilities which were designed to help the sightseer” (Percy, 2). To Percy, true experience comes from within, not without, and this perspective was undoubtedly influenced by the individualistic nature he was forced to adopt throughout his early childhood.

Yet, the story of Percy’s early life is still just half the coin. The other half comes about years later, after he had finished his undergraduate degree and was attending medical school at Columbia University. While working as an intern in a sick ward in Bellevue Hospital, Percy contracted tuberculosis, being forced yet again into isolation from society, this time at a retreat in upstate New York in order to recover from the disease. It was here that, as James A. Crank, writer for the newsletter 64 Parishes, puts it, “Percy read a variety of European existential writers, eventually concluding that science could not explain fundamental questions about man’s existence and purpose” (Crank, 2011). Having lived in an age of technocrats and industrialized warfare, these ideas likely influenced Percy’s views on the rest of society, seeing modern civilization as being fundamentally opposed to the spiritual needs of man, and stripping away his individualism. We see this sense of antipathy to modernity all throughout The Loss of the Creature, such as when Percy states “The technician and the sophomore who loves his textbooks are always offended by the genuine research man because the latter is usually a little vague and always humble before the thing; he doesn’t have much use for the equipment or the jargon” (Percy, 5). Through the lens of two, for lack of a better word, unremarkable individuals, Percy conveys to us this idea that at a fundamental level, our world is made up of uncreative, unthinking people seeking only to conform to preapproved ideas of “how things should be”. It’s a contrast that is only highlighted when compared with someone truly remarkable, the “Great Man”, someone who’s not afraid to question societal standards and fundamentally grasp at the real meaning behind an object, not just its superficial value. This point only goes to highlight a later idea brought up by Crank, that “Given Percy’s life-changing sickness, it is perhaps not surprising that many of his characters are sick: either physically ill or afflicted by a mental malaise that isolates them from the ‘normal’ world” (Crank, 2011). In The Loss of the Creature, the sick individual is not any person in particular, isolated from the society, it is society as a whole, sick with the tradeoffs we’ve made in the name of modernity, and isolated from the normal, natural world that was given to us. In our drive for progress, for understanding, Percy believes we have shrunk away from the creaturelike instinct within us to be curious, to experience things for ourselves and not rely on society for guidance and support.

So he asks us, is progress truly worth the costs we pay for it? A Wall Street banker, in the drive for profit, spends countless hours away from home at his desk, hours he could’ve spent with his family, going on vacations, and simply taking in the world around us. Yet, despite all his effort, his life accomplishments can be wiped away in a single moment, as the stock market crashes, and with it, all that he worked so hard for. Throughout his essay Percy wants us to think critically about the price we’ve paid for our modern civilization; for all our advances, are we truly any better off from the “creatures” within us we’ve killed off to be here? The Loss of the Creature is an essay not only questioning the very foundations of human nature, it is also the story of Percy and his family’s firsthand experiences with the high and low points of societal progress. At the end of the day, we are all born, and we will all die, all that remains is what we do in between these two points, and is it truly worth it if we spend the little time we have on this Earth pursuing such seemingly insignificant goals like wealth and power? Doing so, we only lose touch with the fundamental, natural forces that we are composed of.
